name: Boston Public Garden
reviews: Wonderful place amidst crowded commercial zone. Have been there a couple of times, it’s a huge park! People footfall is high throughout the day. At times small musical events, food stalls are setup to make the park more attractive. The ducks 🦆 , large squirrels 🐿 and pond are perfect for photography! Good place to have a walk chatting with friends and family.

The Garden is a beautiful place to walk around.  If you bring some fruit or nuts along, you can put it down for the squirrels to eat as they are adorable. There are always new fresh flowers in the spring and summer. In the fall, the foliage is pretty.

What a cool place to visit! If you’re visiting Boston this park is a must see. It is home to the iconic statue of George Washington, well lit walking paths and a pond that freezes in the winter. I really enjoyed my time here at this park.

If you're in Boston, you have to see it's Central Park! Is it better than NYC's Central Park? Maybe not. However, it's smaller, tighter and in some ways more complete. An absolute treat to be in, the place is riddled with monuments and sculptures. There's a great couple of ponds in the middle with an iconic iron bridge over them. Nearby are some fabulous stone fountains - each with their own sets of sculptures. To a nature and architecture lover, this place is a delight. 

Enjoy your picnic lunch here or just stroll about. Hardly will you find cause to be disappointed.

This park is by far one of the nicest spots in the whole city! It's perfect for a leisurely stroll around the lake and through the gardens. There are plenty of beautiful flowers and trees, and it is a breath of fresh air in the heart of Boston. You can follow the path around the lake, or sit on the grass or a bench and people watch. There are usually people playing instruments and it is a real pleasure to relax and enjoy the music. But be careful! The park is home to a literal horde of fluffy squirrels with no fear of people at all! If you take your eyes off your food you may find that you accidentally donated your snack to the squirrels of the park!

name: Faneuil Hall Marketplace
address: 4 S Market St, Boston, MA 02109, USA
reviews: Nice cherry marketplace with ample stalls with everything from hand-made goods to various foods. Interesting for discovering new trends such as healthy products, good also for gifts. Tends to be rather expensive for the chain stores and chain restaurants but at least for those then you can feel that they'll have a good standard of service and products/services. I found that the people working here were friendly and respectful, not pushy, which I appreciated.

This is a pretty neat historical marketplace and meeting place. The national parks people love talking about the history and the building and they are all super nice. I loved being in a place where our founding fathers were. The meeting place upstairs is large and there are some really awesome paintings to help you feel the historical significance of the place. And you should definitely talk with the parks people because they know everything about the place and the famous things that happened there.

This place is BEAUTIFUL. What a wonderful experience for a tourist. The lighting is gorgeous, the outdoor area extremely well maintained, and it has a nice variety of shops. Definitely a must-see for any visitor new to the area. If I had one complaint, it would be the prices are a bit steep, but it's to be expected given the location.

What I had: I would recommend the Indian place, their curry chicken is not dry and very tender. The curry itself was very savoury and did not have overpowering spices. You can taste before ordering. The portions were good as well.

Location Review
Pros:
-Lots of food selection (ranging from Indian, Chinese, seafood, ice cream, baked goods, etc)
-Well insulated and ventilated (not overly hot or cold)
-Food is decently priced 
-Lots of samples to try before you make your decision
-Surprisingly clean, staff constantly cleaning after patrons
-Garbage cans everywhere

Cons:
-Seating could use some improvements, there's limited seating and it's very packed (hard to find seating, but people eat quick; chairs are a bit uncomfortable no backing)
-The market itself feels cramped because there's always a lot of people

Historical. Enjoy the street performers (don't forget to tip them, they are worth it). Oodles of food options. If you are looking for authentic Boston cuisine try elsewhere like the North End, which is right across the street. Otherwise you can find plenty to eat here.  

Shopping options include everything from Crocs to comic books to clothing. Be prepared for crowds.

 Make sure to check out the Christmas light show during the holidays.

name: Boston Common
reviews: Beautiful, open area in the middle of the city with varying terrain. Many vendors line the commons. You can sit on the benches or on the grass. There's a wading pool in the summer that converts to a skating rink in the winter. Nice view of Beacon Hill and the state capital building. All right next to the Park Square transit station.

It's a wonderful place. We walked down Joy Street from Beacon House and sat for a while on a bench in the sun. Lots of people out on a beautiful spring day, but enough room to easily maintain social distance. We headed west over to the Public Garden. Also great but a very different sort of space.

Great place to  visit.. I live near Boston and enjoy walking the park. Plenty to see if you love to people watch. If you're from out of town and look for place  from all the city traffic come here to decompress.

Stunning! We visited in May and the gardens were amazing! We loved strolling through the pathways and seeing all the statues. All the history and sights were amazing. The sidewalks are very wide an accommodate a lot of people. There were lots of places to stop, sit and relax.

One of my favorite things to do. Grab a coffee, walk through the common, find a bench and sit and read or people watch. It's much cleaner than it was. It's obviously not as much fun to sit and read in winter, but on a warm spring day it's great to dip your feet into the frog pond and act like a kid again.

name: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
reviews: So many beautiful pieces and exhibits. Definitely too much to fully take in during one visit (if you walk slowly and stop to stare at almost everything, like I do). I'd probably skip the cafe and save my appetite and wallet for the good restaurants well within walking distance of the museum.

Great job on the Nubian Exhibit!  I love the different "voices" that appear in the written materials.  I was surprised and impressed at the discussion about the white-washing of Egypt b/the entire East African region shares the same art, culture, science and history (recently traveled to Ethiopia).  I think trials that the MFA is experiencing regarding race reflects your ongoing willingness to change and stick your neck out.  It's hard, but as an African American whose been visiting the museum since childhood, I really appreciate the change.  Thank you and nice job!

Classic art from the European and American masters and historical exhibits plus modern art. Modern art doesn't interest me but the more traditional art took my breath away multiple times. My husband and I will be going back again as there was so much to see that we didn't get to it all. It was truly a pleasure to see art from masters like Botticelli.

This museum is not for the light of heart. With arts from around the globe, this museum will take a full day if you stop and admire/read every placard. 3 floors span the massive location with a lunch restaurant located close to the middle. Bring your walking shoes, a 60gb SD card and be ready to learn and be inspired by the massive collection of fine arts and history.

I am a member of the MFA it is through the park behind my apartment..It is ever changing offers studio and degree classes.. The art is amazing, the restaurants are all wonderful.. The outside garden is peaceful...We are so lucky to have an amazing museum right in our backyard!

name: Fenway Park
reviews: Loved Fenway Park! My girlfriend and I were coming in to the U.S through New Hampshire and decided to make a quick stop through Boston to see if we could do some quick sight seeing. It was like 1:45 in the morning so there was no one there. We ran around the entire perimeter of the park taking pictures with all the statues and signs. There was an open House of Blues right outside it and a guy offered to take pictures of us. Over all it was a fantastic time. Would go again. But not during a game, God I hate baseball.

What can you say about Fenway? It was amazing! We had the tour before the game and found out so many cool things about it's history and who have played there. Our seats were pretty good! Although, the game went into extra innings, and we were there until just past midnight, the staff was okay with letting us move in as close as we wanted! So much to see about the history as well.

Take me out to the ball game.  Can’t wait for the 2020 season to begin.  I drive from 4.5 hours away to come to games at this stadium.   The history here is like no other and you’re always guaranteed fun and action when you come to a ballgame at Fenway Park.  The food is tasty and available at each and every turn you make.  The prices are reasonable but the thing that sticks out the most is the superior service from all the staff.  Excellent job to everyone and a special thanks to the management for running such a well oiled machine.
One of the last old school ball parks left. I recommend everyone take in a game or at least a tour of the park. It’s truly a historic site everyone should experience at least once.

You guys even looking at this?

Its Fenway...
Not much is needed to be said.

Restaurants outside the park are awesome.

Inside you'll find ample seating and accommodating food sales. You know you want to come try out Boston's famous, home of the Red Sox.

name: Museum of Science
address: 1 Museum Of Science Driveway, Boston, MA 02114, USA
reviews: This place is an absolute gem for children in order to spark their minds as scientists. Not only does it include exhibits but there are many interactive activities to do within. I felt like this would be a wonderful opportunity to bring kids to learn and captivate interest in science. Being a college student, I still found some of these shows/exhibits rather entertaining and I'm still learning from it. Although on the smaller side, I think this museum was an incredible experience. I highly recommend the electricity show. Parking was >$20 for about 5 hours but was attached to the building. The museum was easy to find and the overall experience was a bunch of fun

There was an amazing amount of interactive stuff to do at the museum. We also went to see a live animal show which was really fun. We were a group of adults and it was nice that everything was aimed at people of all ages. We were lucky enough to be there at the same time as the Dog exhibit, which is where we ended up spending most of our time. 

The view of the river when you first walk in is stunning as well. We were visiting from out of town so it was amazing to see the river and learn about the waves at the same time.

Still my favorite New England museum and worth the hefty price of admission and extras. I bring lunch for the family in order to save time and money. The exhibits are ever-changing so our visits stay fresh and informative, appealing to all ages. It is always super clean and the staff is very helpful. They have lockers and rest rooms, including a family private restroom in the green wing on the second floor. And the famous Boston Duck Tours begin and end out front if you want to add another fun adventure to your day!

This amazing treasure, that brought me so much joy as a kid, is constantly being updated. Took two middle-school boys today and they really enjoyed it. Best of all, they could walk around by themselves and explore at their own pace. A younger boy and I spent the afternoon together and I was amazed how focused he was. We all need to go back and see the other 2/3's of the Museum. Can't wait!

You definitely get your money's worth here, this place is huge! We didn't even attend any of the planetarium shows (we wanted to, just ran out of time) and we were at the museum for several hours. There are many interactive exhibits that are both fun and educational. Would definitely recommend going, it's a perfect trip for families/children as well. We will be returning during one of our next Boston trips to check out the planetarium!

name: New England Aquarium
reviews: What a beautiful aquarium! This place is laid out vertically, so stairs and ramps are a must to get around. The open air penguin exhibit is extraordinary, and the electric eel tank is absolutely mesmerizing. Almost all the animals appear to be well taken care of, with the sole exception of the outdoor harbor seal exhibit, which seems very small and a bit unkempt given the size of the animals. Overall it was a lovely and educational experience. Will definitely return.

I love this aquarium! They have penguins in the front area, and you can watch them during their feeding time which is super fun and exciting! The building has this really cool spiral-like design where you can walk up the levels and see all kinds of different aquatic creatures. I learned about so many cool creatures, and made some really special memories with my family! They also have a seal exhibit and a sea lion exhibit, and both are so fun to watch! They're so cute and playful, and they have so much personality! I totally want to come here again! One of my favorite memories is of the garden eels on the top floor, they're so cute and peaceful! The photo is from the sea lion exhibit, they were really active and talkative during our visit!

This place was so much fun! Petting sharks and rays was the FIRST stop - amazing! The displays host unique, beautiful, interesting varieties of marine life, with friendly staff to answer questions. Live shows and feeding times enhance the experience. Very family-friendly. So much to see!

New England Aquarium is a giant fish bowl teeming with sea creatures of all sizes, shapes and colours, and is the centrepiece of downtown Boston. There are over 800 different marine animals, including seals, sea dragons, stingrays, sharks and penguins. The main attraction is a unique central tank with small sharks, many varieties of fish and a huge sea turtle. There are daily presentations, behind-the-scenes tours, family programs and other special events year-round. This is a true aquatic experience!

The New England Aquarium is a gem.  It's not the biggest, most spectacular aquarium around, however, it has a tremendous collection and a very unique story.  It's a perfect place to bring the kids, good friends, and family for a very reasonable price.  The member benefits are quite nice as well, if you're considering supporting the aquarium as a local.  It's in a terrific location within a short walk of all sorts of great food and additional attractions.  You can make a very full day of it at NEAQ.  The staff is awesome, mostly all volunteer, and every one of them has great knowledge of the sea life they tend to .  It's a great day trip, or if you want to split things up, you can take a wale watch cruise right of the adjacent dock.  Highly recommend!

name: Boston Tea Party Ships & Museum
reviews: Fantastic experience with interactive and historically accurate hosts. From the hall of where is started to the replica ships that started the birth of America. You're able to throw replica tea into the harbor with ropes attached. Participation is critical only if you want to feel highly involved with the actual history portion. You are led into the basement history museum which you get to see and actual, and only surviving tea crate. Great place and would highly recommend it!

Absolutely worth the time and money. The information is presented in a way that is interactive and keeps you interested. The staff is also very well informed and will answer any and all questions. The gift shop is one of the best priced I have ever seen. We highly recommend going and learning about our nation's history. This place keeps you hooked the whole way through.

Another great historical place to visit. All the people there wear, talk, and act like the 16 and 17 hundreds. The ships are really kool. The tour they offer is way worth it and you learn a lot about the Tea Party. The have and you can taste the 5 teas they threw in the water. The scones and muffins were really good. To me, a must see if your ever in Boston.

Nice place! Nice people! Very interesting program! You will be surprised by it - this is not regular boring historic museum! This is cool and funny.

Around $60 for two persons, parking was $34. 

Enjoy!

You need to do the tour to do the museum and are led around be reenactors. It is fun and you get to "throw tea" into the Boston harbor. The cafe and tea shop also had reasonably priced tea and baked goods. I recommend getting your tickets online in advance because on busy days the tour times fill up fast. We had to wait over an hour after we arrived for the next available tour.

name: Skywalk Observatory
reviews: Such a wonderful 360 view of Boston! We had a blast watching the sun go down, picking out the places we visited, watching the city light up after dark. It wasn't terribly busy, and there was lots of space to grab a seat and watch the sun go down. There's history and fun facts about Boston, including interactive exhibits. Plus, military members get in for free!

Such a wonderful 360 view of Boston! We had a blast watching the sun go down, picking out the places we visited, watching the city light up after dark. It wasn't terribly busy, and there was lots of space to grab a seat and watch the sun go down. There's history and fun facts about Boston, including interactive exhibits. Plus, military members get in for free! Such a wonderful 360 view of Boston! We had a blast watching the sun go down, picking out the places we visited, watching the city light up after dark. It wasn't terribly busy, and there was lots of space to grab a seat and watch the sun go down. There's history and fun facts about Boston, including interactive exhibits. Plus, military members get in for free! Students has some discounts

A good place to visit in Boston. Spectacular views from the top. I would suggest visiting on a clear day for best viewing. It was a little expensive though. Nevertheless, it is a nice view. Can see many other attractions and landmarks in Boston. It really makes you look at the area differently.

Great views!! We didn't wait in the line too much and admission fee covered the audio explanation of the buildings visible from the observatory. You can even see the Boston airport from Skywalk. I recommend going there early in the morning.

Must visit place in Boston! You simply cannot miss being awestruck by the amazing views that the Skywalk Observatory offers! It also shares the history of Boston in some nice documentary short movies. You can spend a good hour just walking there, soaking in the breathtaking views and reading all about Boston history. Loved every minute being there!

name: Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University
reviews: So this place is quite nice for a stroll in the park. It is quite large the selection of trees is very abundant there are many dandelions in the whole ambience of the park is quite nice. This park is maintained by Harvard which is kind of cool. But is located in a weird part of Boston so take that as you wish.

It's beautiful and you don't feel like you are in the city. However if you go to Peter's Hill you can see the city skyline and have a nice sunset. You can even see the 4th of July fireworks from Peter's Hill! Go get lost and maybe find a tree you have never seen before, like the Dawn Redwoods 😉

This is a beautiful arboretum, owner and operated by Harvard University. We went there on a cool and sunny summer day and had a fantastic time wandering the winding the paths. Many of the trees are labeled, allowing you to brush up on your botany skills! I’d highly recommend coming here when you get the chance. Be aware that there wasn’t any food or drink at the visitor center, so bring your own. There are bathrooms though.

The Arnold Arboretum is a beautiful, little hidden treasure in Boston! When you walk through the park it almost feels like you're no longer in the city, but roaming around a mystical forest in some far-away land. The trees, in the Spring, are always so vibrant and colorful. Definitely a great place to visit to relax and reflect!
Very clean and walkable park.  Not much to see in the winter though.  Ponds are frozen so fun to skip rocks across.

name: Boston Children's Museum
reviews: Very good place for kids between the age 3 and 10. Kids above 10 might enjoy as well, but will have limited engagements. The museum has 3 floors with some water related play areas that kids seem to like the most. Overall experience was good. Don't forget to pack your food if you plan to go there. They have a separate dining area with about 30-40 seating, but do not have a food court as such. There were a couple of snack vending machines which I think will not be enough to spend a full day at the museum.

Good museum for children under 12 (my opinion).  Many hands on activities for the kids.  Sufficient bathrooms and "rest" places for parents.  Decent food option.  You can practically spend a whole day here.  Lots of activities to keep active kids busy.

I am absolutely floored by the experience. The 2nd floor has a 0-3 only play area WITH a crawling-only section. Hands on stuff everywhere; STEAM Lab, Art Lab, Construction Area, and tons of installations ready for climbing. Eating areas with open spaces, microwaves, sinks, changing areas... Like, $18 for a whole day of energy-burning fun? Do it.

The staff is phenomenal. They have music nights and other events... If you got little runts, they will love it.

I just wish they had a good napping area.

Wonderful museum for kids, but not good value for the very young (~1yo). My wife and I took our daughter to check it out, and they have a play space that was great for our little girl, but we had to pay 3 full admissions to get there, on top of expensive parking -- there are play spaces around the city that charge only for the child and are a fraction of the cost per ticket while providing similar or better experiences.

This place is amazing, my 9 year old has been coming here since he was a baby and still loves it there! There is so much for kids to do, there are rooms with passive activities, and rooms with very exciting activities. There is  something for everyone to do, regardless of a child's personality/style. I highly recommend it.

name: Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum
reviews: Imagine that you are going inside someone's 'home' that is huge, classic, unpredictable, full of memorable expensive personal collections from around the world, blended with the beauty of a tropical garden as the center that connected all rooms on three floors. That's at least how I feel. All rooms at every level is differently designed and colored by the owner for different purposes. One can be grander because of its wood elements, while others are grand with its metal or fabric elements. You can see paintings, jewellery, clothes, books, tapestry, stained glass, pottery, furniture, sculpture, letters, and many more. Enjoy the freshness of the garden's fresh view and fresh air after leaving or while seeing each room. You will feel more inspired and peaceful. I always thought that that's the garden is for. Sometimes there will be activities for children to paint, a small concert to enjoy in the garden, a free tour to follow, or talks to attend. Check the brochure and ask someone with 'ASK ME' pin. Check out the gift shop and the restaurant. Oh, one more, try to search about the story when the paintings were stolen in the '90s, and the frames were left hanging empty until today. It adds to your excitement of its mystery when you found them inside!

There are many great things about this fabulous collection of art works but there is a relatively new one which you may not know about . . . the AUDIO TOUR the museum makes available through your own cell phone or other  mobile device. 

There are two outstanding features to this great functionality, well, actually three, outstanding benefits:  1) no standing in line to pick up or drop off the museum's headset; 2) no need to wear the museum's headset which could potentially bring with it illness-inducing germs; and 3) the ability to listen to the complete tour of the museum without  actually being there.  You can listen to the audio tour prior to arriving at the museum from anyplace you have an internet connection.  This is a big plus because when you are actually at the museum you already know so much about where you are and what you are looking at.  It allows you to pick and choose where to spend your time without feeling like you are maybe missing something you will later really wished you had been able to take the time to hear/see.

Beautiful museum that does a wonderful job of seamlessly integrating the collection with the building and architecture. Be sure to get a tour to understand the history and intention of the museum, it goes a long way to fully appreciating the space and its history. There's a nice wine bar to help set the atmosphere, and on Thursdays, there's live music in the evenings. Great date night idea!

Really beautiful museum with an interesting art collection. Different area of the museum's are theme based on time period and/or region of the world. In center of the property is a large courtyard and beautiful garden. I honestly could have sat next to the garden for hours. It's hard to really absorb everything in one visit so I will definitely be returning!

***Free entry for people named Isabella!!!*** This is truly one of the coolest museums I've ever visited anywhere in the world. There is something for everyone, whether you like architecture, gardens, paintings, the renaissance era, drawings, sculptures, furniture, antique decorations or artifacts. There is even intrigue about the theft several decades ago, would definitely recommend a walling or audio tour! Museum staff is very warm and helpful and their new wing also has amazing and rotating displays. It's not a huge space but it would definitely take days to really see every nook and cranny (considering they're all filled to the brim!) In addition to the mansion filled with art and centuries-old items of interest, there is a library, a cafe, a gift shop and other amenities. Couldn't recommend more!

name: USS Constitution Museum
address: Building 22, Charlestown Navy Yard, Charlestown, MA 02129, USA
reviews: As a US Navy veteran this place is as close as it gets to the root of it all. Just thrilling to walk in so much history. You feel it. It's utterly palpable. The knowledgeable sailors aboard this legend must be so proud to be able to walk in the footsteps of the proud past and share with the people today. I feel refreshed for having been able to partake of this incredible proud lady. I felt the sway of the ship that LIVES the history of our beloved nation. Just WOW.❤🇺🇸⚓

**If you are an adult, you need a government-issued ID to get on the ship itself.** Extremely thorough and highly interactive museum. Lots of things to read for the adults and simulations, examples, and activities for kids to touch and interact with. "Old Iron Sides" - the USS Constitution itself - is really neat. You can visit three decks of the ship, and there are Navy personnel present to give explanations and answer questions.

This was a nice place with useful information but it’s not for adults.  In the context of a museum for children it does a really great job with its interactive exhibits.  I was interested in learning about the history of the USS Constitution, how it’s changed over the centuries, and it’s cultural significance over time, but as an adult with no children I got nothing out of this.

One of my favorite museums as a kid. This place was great. You can actually go on the ship and walk around. The staff is super knowledgeable and polite. It is a really cool experience I feel like a lot of people don’t know about. I would rather bring someone here than the old north church, it is much more engaging. Plus the view from right there is really hard to beat!

Today's visit was quite unexpected and fantastic! During school vacation week they are offering a Lego build with all kinds of bricks and a contest throughout the week. It also coincides with the Miniature Master models. Amazing!!! We had lots of fun and plan to go again when we have more time to walk through the regular museum displays. Today we just focused on the special exhibits. Also hope to go aboard the ship next time. Gift shop reasonably priced and lots of variety.  *Admission by donation! ♡ it!!!

name: Boston National Historical Park
address: Building 5, Charlestown Navy Yard, Boston, MA 02109, USA
reviews: Prime early American history. It's a great park, and a nice walk to finish off the freedom trail. Do not climb the stairs, you'll regret it.
A great place to visit. Stop by and pick up a little bit of our nations past. Beautiful architecture and foliage.

Another great park in this tourist-friendly Boston city. You really don't have to be a history buff to enjoy this park. Contrary to what you'd read, the size of this park allows for many outdoor activities abd only if you feel like it, you can pay attention to the war memorabilia.
Great historical information! Lots to see and do. If the weather is nice, it's worth walking around. Traffic can be hectic, but we went right in peak tourist season. Otherwise everything was great.
Great historic spot to learn about Boston colonial times and the revolution. The building is well preserved and the staff is very friendly. This place is on the heart of the downtown Boston.

name: Charles River Esplanade
address: Charles River Esplanade, Boston, MA 02116, USA
reviews: Stunning views. Great walkways. You really lose yourself in the cityscape. Beautiful sky views at night.  Unobstructed shorelines. A must visit when I come to the city.

Central Park it is not. It’s really just a longish trail along the river. It’s pretty, though. And it’s free. 

Let’s face it. It’s expensive to live in Boston. I don’t even live in Boston and it’s expensive to just live near Boston. And on a slushy day in February you might have to ask yourself “why am I living here?”  Florida is a lot cheaper and does t get nearly as much snow. 

Well the Esplanade is one of the places you can visit to remind yourself why you live here. It’s a long park on the Charles River  it has excellent views of the city and of the Charles. It has willows (my wife’s favorite tree) and geese and on a good day it might have a heron or two. 

In the morning people bike and run around, either on their way somewhere or just exercising. In the evening people do the same, or just take a leisurely stroll with the one they love.

And I’m sure they have places like that in Florida, but if it’s spring summer or fall the weather can’t be beat, and it’s right next to a big city.

Is gorgeous there, many outdoor activities you can do during the springtime. From kayaking, fishing walking around, boat sailing classes, going around with your bicycle or running. It's a nice blossom and near the river area for you to enjoy.

Nothing feels as calm and peaceful than witnessing the sunset against the skyline of Boston. Beautiful view and I would consider this to be a tourist attractions or its spectacular view from the waterfront.

Is gorgeous there, many outdoor activities you can do during the summer time. From kayaking, fishing walking around, boat sailing classes, going around with your bicycle or running.  It's a nice green and near the river area for you to enjoy.

name: The Paul Revere House
reviews: This is a great stop on the Freedom Trail. The cost was acceptable, and the rooms and storytelling were interesting. No pictures were allowed inside, but the outside and the visitor's center allowed photos. I recommend this as an important site for American history. Not to mention, I never knew how much Paul Revere had done after his ride. Very interesting man.

When we travel, we like to visit historical sites and learn about he places as are staying. We learned about Paul Revere in school in the Midwest, but as an adult, I think much more about what his life was like and why he chose to take his stand. It was neat to be able to walk through a home he lived with and see some of the furniture he owned, to learn more about his wives, children, and career. It's only 5.00 to enter, bit do bring cash. It is operated by a non profit that depends on donations. If you are Interested in history, don't hesitate to go!

Fun little place that has a lot of history behind it. Cheap to get into and quick to see everything in it. The tour guides are knowledgeable and friendly. Seems like it would be a nice place for kids.

Interesting look at how people lived in Paul Revere's time period. Also provides some good facts about Paul Revere and his life and family. It is very short and the house only has a few rooms. The whole self guided tour took about 10 minutes. The top level is not open for viewing (third floor). The people working inside were wonderful. Tons of knowledge and happy to answer any questions and provide information. I was amazed at how much they knew. If you go check this out (it's only $5) make sure to chat with the people there, they really are want makes it worth it.

The place that has a lot of history behind it. You get into and quick to see everything in it, But photos aren't allowed. the price of tickets starts from 5$. The tour guides are very friendly. it is a kids friendly also.The home was built about 1680 on the site of the former parsonage of the Second Church of Boston.

name: Franklin Park Zoo
address: 1 Franklin Park Rd, Boston, MA 02121, USA
reviews: What isn't too love about this zoo? My partner and I spent HOURS here over the summer getting lost in all of the beautiful attractions and looking at the critters. The bird cage was one of my favorite places, especially with the bird seed lollipops they give you to feed the little guys. The zoo was WAY bigger than we thought, because the zoo map made it look pretty small. Parking was super easy and convenient, and we arrived just after opening, so we made it inside in less than five minutes of arriving at the gate. The animals looked healthy and well taken care of, and all of the enclosures were well kept and clean. The goats were a bit tired due to the 80 degree heat, but the ice cream booths and AC in the shops made it a nice experience for the two of us. The gift shop was quaint, and not as expensive as you'd expect for a Boston attraction. We left with some cute souvenirs, and the lunch there was excellent and had very large portions. Enough for two people to share one meal and still have too much food. The only downside was that we arrived too late in the season to see the butterfly enclosure, but the rest of the views made it all worth it.

Great for kids. Easy to walk the whole zoo in a day. It may be a small zoo but it has many animals. There are also small attractions for young children. It could use better food options and parking. Prices are to be expected for the area.
Great place for families. Lots to do. The animals looked healthy and well cared for. We were there for a birthday party. Perfect setting for that.

Great zoo for young kids. You can see all the exhibits in one day. There is also a nice playground. My biggest complaint is the lack of food options, but you can definitely pack your own lunch. Parking is free but can get pretty full on busy days.
It’s good for kids. I brought tickets using library card ... it’s worth to enjoy with kids.. it is having pay area also, animals are few but covered most important ones

name: Old North Church
reviews: I highly recommend touring the old church if visiting Boston.  I also recommend paying the small amount for the “behind the scenes” tour which will take you up to where the bells are rung and through the crypt below.  It is exhilarating and humbling to stand in a place where so much history and well known people have been present. The church itself is beautiful.  Our tour guide was knowledgeable, articulate and exuded a pure passion for the past.  Don’t forget to tour the chocolate shop next door for some colonial chocolate!

It's a really small church. It isn't particularly beautiful inside. The historians inside are cool and will talk to you as long as you want but not even they can save this place from being in actuality rather irrelevant. 

Save your money. Take a photo on the outside. Look up the Longfellow poem on your phone and call it good.

Beautiful church with great passive info opportunities, but I was VERY disappointed with the tour. The guide seemed rude and apathetic and more interested in making snarky remarks than encouraging a love of history in our group. I was not impressed with him or the girl who ended our tour by speed-reading through a well-written account of the Church's history. She also seemed disinterested and apathetic. I hope they can improve their interpreter team for the better.

Amazing piece of history. If you are visiting Boston on holiday or for any reason at all stop by for a second to take in the history and the beautiful surroundings. The building itself dates back hundreds of years.
Very cool to be in a place where so much history happened! The workers are all very knowledgeable and I enjoyed every minute

name: John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum
reviews: Thoroughly enjoyable experience here! This is a wonderful museum and library. They do a fantastic job of depicting JFK's life and work. The architecture and landscaping are also really nice. If you walk out the back, you can walk around Boston harbour with great views of the city. The really enjoyed learning more about this great president.

Wonderful museum! Just went here yesterday with my Leadership club from my school. I love the exhibits and everything about JFK! It was my first time being here. I would definitely want to go again! The staff was super nice!

This museum was inspiring.  It reminded us of how things were, how happy and proud we were to be Americans.   This museum made us sad.  It reminded us of how things were,  how happy and proud,  not Like now.  Thank you for the upbeat,  factual reminders of a great man and our great nation.  We can only help history will repeat itself.

I went into this place with 0 expectations. I hadn’t heard anything about it and no one had recommended it to me - I simply wanted to learn more about Kennedy as I feel like I was fairly uneducated about his life and accomplishments. 

This was both an immersive and informative experience that I would recommend to anyone visiting Boston. The video exhibits were really well produced and engaging and the walk-through exhibits were brilliant. 

My personal favourite section was the real life audio recordings from the Cuban missile crisis debate - you can honestly feel the tension and anxiety of the whole situation through listening to the tapes.

The design of the building was unlike anything I’ve been to - the large yet minimalistic style made it seem really futuristic which was a really nice contrast to the exhibit itself.

Really great looking monument and informative history details inside. Best show is the Cuban missle crisis. Worth going, takes about an hour to browse through, but easily you can spend half a day if you are an enthusiast!

name: Bunker Hill Monument
reviews: Really nice park to walk around at any time, with informational markers to describe the important battle that took place there. The climb to the top of the monument can be pretty sweaty during the summer, especially if it's crowded - there are a lot of stairs and the passage is narrow. But it's a fun experience to get to the top and look around. I'm a bit of a history buff, and I highly recommend the store/museum across the street to get a greater appreciation of the battle

Walk out of downtown Boston and take a little walk through historical part of town and up this 296 stair monument.  You’ll be greeted by lovely views of the city, Cambridge and the waters.  Loads of history in this little park including a free museum (across the street from the monument) and during different parts of the year there will be people dressed in colonial wear so that you can get a feel what that was like.  All of this is free, educational and very entertaining.

We decided to go explore the city and ended up climbing this monument, after 290 steps up (which sounds alot easier then it was) we got to see the whole city from a really cool monument. The signs out front say it's going to be hard to climb and it definitely was harder then we thought. This is definitely a place to go and visit if you are around.

This monument has 294 stairs.  The top is amazing. The entire experience is free of charge and managed by the U.S. Park service. Everyone was very nice.  The process requires  a person to comfortably walk upstairs with little opportunity or options for breaks.  Enjoy!

The only way to commemorate skirmishes of the past with good taste is to leave a mark that is nice looking or has a sentimental value to the lost ones. This monument has both and also grandeur. Climbing the steps gives you a great view of the neighborhoods of Boston.

name: Boston Harbor Islands National and State Park
reviews: Fort-showcasing island that will captivate your attention for a while. It doesn't get too busy so you'll have a nice view for awesome pictures of the harbor and historical buildings. This has to be one of the most clean touristy island I've been to.

Beautiful and informative. Perfect day in the harbor with great views of the city from the sea. The connections between the islands are very convenient and easy to use if you want to do island hopping.

Spectacle was a good day trip for picnicking, going for a light hike and dip in the harbor. Be careful with how much you bring, as the park is carry on, carry off. And do not swim on the boat side of the dock. Otherwise it’s a  nice escape from the city. Hard to believe that people lived here year round!

We visited George's Island. They have Fort Warren there. It was very interesting. They have a few runs during the day, as well as guided tours. You can also amble around on your own if you want. There is a visitors center where you can see information on the history of the fort, and a brief video. There are restrooms there as well. There is a rule that whatever you bring to the island, you take when you leave. There are no garbage barrels there. You also should bring food and beverages, as there are none on the island. You may purchase beverages and snacks on the boat going there. Definitely worth going. There are a bunch of islands but you would have to start early to see more than one. Check them out!

I went to Spectacle and Georges during this visit on a hot July Saturday. The ferry from Long Wharf to Spectacle took about 15 minutes. Spectacle has great walking trails and a guarded beach along with changing rooms. The visitor center houses some information on the island’s varied history along with a sea glass mural, made with items found on the beach. Photos can be taken of the sea glass and pottery but must not be removed from island. The vistas of the Boston Harbor waterfront area are great from the hiking trails as well as the beach and dock.

name: Franklin Park
address: 1 Franklin Park Rd, Boston, MA 02121, USA
reviews: They have added more life to the place. It looks nicer ! Before it was looking sad but really happy it's made a change for the best. I've had my kids coming since they were little. This is a big  part of Dorchester and happy they didn't let it go down. Love the animals!
Tranquility, generally safe at Jamaica Plain location. Met my husband over there and got married. Now working for a facility located just in, or at least very nearby.

I have been to Franklin Park Zoo many times starting when I was a kid. I recently attended a breakfast at the zoo, specifically with the sloths the experience was very cool and engaging. The breakfast options though were lacking. I suggest getting breakfast after. There was the option to walk around the zoo after which was very cool because you could be there before everyone else and all of the zookeepers were telling quite interesting facts about the animals that you wouldn't normally hear when the zoo is crowded.

The Tropical Rainforest was Amazing! "Little Joe" and friends were mesmerizing! We could have stayed all day observing them. Zoo Keeper, Celia (?) was sooooo informative and it was a pleasure meeting her and learning so much about the Franklin Park Zoo's gorillas!

The kids always love a trip to the Franklin Park Zoo. It's spread out over really nicely maintained grounds.  It's a little small, but still had a nice variety of exhibits and animals to learn about with great descriptions at every exhibit.  There are a few great areas for younger children to play and rest from all of the, you know Zoo stuff.

name: Trapology Boston
address: 177 Tremont St 2nd floor, Boston, MA 02111, USA
reviews: This place is awesome. The quality of the puzzles and props is much better than what we experienced at other places. The puzzles logically led the way to the escape. We did two on the same day and were lucky to have Rachel as our Game Master for both. She made it really fun and helped us just the right amount. Keep up the good work.

Their rooms are so well done and thought out! They have now 5 rooms and they design in-house so you know a lot of care is put into their build outs. The rooms are definitely challenging, but their puzzles make sense and are on theme. The staff is super friendly and helpful. To top it off, they're in a great location with amazing views of the Common. If you're looking to do an escape room in Boston, make sure to check them out!

My friends and I did a room on Sunday and it was extremely fun and stimulating. I was with a pretty big group and we all agreed we would love to go back and try the other rooms. The place is unique compared to other escape rooms I’ve been to and the staff was accommodating. Our game keeper, Kevin, was helpful and funny. He made us feel so much better about not completing the challenge and was very knowledgeable. Can’t wait to go back!
We did the steam punk train room and had a blast! Karen was a super host and was able to really help us move along… Even though we were such experts that we needed very little. ha ha...

Trapology is a fantastic escape room venue in downtown Boston. The puzzles are pretty darn good - most can be solved without unreasonable leaps of logic, and the rooms are thematic and well designed. A few rooms that I've done (no spoilers ahead) involving a separated team as well as handcuffing team members was unique, though not necessarily beneficial to the experience. Regardless, these design choices worked with the theme and gave us some good laughs.

Will gladly continue to try rooms here.

name: Rose Kennedy Greenway
reviews: A wonderful oasis of trees, flowers, mini gardens and outdoor art works in downtown Boston right next to South Station. This is a beautiful respite for the weary bus and train travelers with a stop-over in Boston, visitors to the Boston Harbor area and all the hard-working people in the downtown district. The Greenway Park meanders from South Station to the Aquarium and the North End. It is intricately designed so that many mini gardens open up within the park. Outdoor sculptures and murals add an exciting touch to the many unique areas marked by blocks of granite, stone steps or mini plazas. Truly a gem and a beautiful addition to the Boston Harbor neighborhood.

Beautiful green and public space for residents! Little ones can enjoy the fountains or just have a nice lay on the grass with a stunning view of the city skyline. Or take a swing on their swing chairs.
In the former shadow of the elevated highway now grows this modern classic tradition of public green space. Take a swing, pull up a chair, walk along the paths, a true gem.

I love going to this Greenway. 

It’s centrally located for a good time:
To one side is the North End (Little Italy) and to the other side Boston Public Market and Union Oyster House. You’re also less than a half-mile from the Wharf and Aquarium.

This greenway is great for:
kids, families, friends, couples and if you’re doing a meetup group. They have splash zones for the kids, and you’ll see students and picnickers everyday. 

The Views: 
The trees and flowers are well kept and beautiful. It has a nice view of the old historical parts of Boston as well as the skyline. 

The park is safe from 7am till 9pm. I haven’t visited outside those hours so I can’t make any claims. But generally speaking it’s well-lit and there are plenty of people including park maintenance and police/rangers.
Nice park to walk through with some water features for the kids.

name: The Mary Baker Eddy Library
reviews:
Showed up after reading about this hidden gem on a Wednesday morning, tickets were $6 and there were 10 people (7 adults) in the 10:40am tour group.  Our guide was WONDERFUL, very knowledgeable and outgoing, and made the tour experience better.  

If you’ve never been, 100% urge you to visit!  A very interesting way to spend 20 minutes, the building is beautiful and the tour is fun for anyone.

We took this quick tour of the Mapparium. If you have time to fit it in your schedule, I highly recommend. It doesn't take long and is $6 per person. Unfortunately you can't take photos inside. It's pretty cool though once inside. It's really just like standing inside the middle of a globe. Pretty cool!

The Mapparium is an incredible place. The lady who gave our tour was well spoken and friendly. I love maps and the experience of seeing a globe in this unique way really puts the whole world into perspective. If you are thinking of going here, just do it. It’s a fun activity!

We enjoyed the Mapparium! At $6 per person, it is good value for money as you get to stand inside the middle of the globe and are given a quick tour by a guide. You can't take photos inside the globe which wasn’t a major problem as it allowed everyone to take it all in. The acoustics inside the globe were fascinating! I’d recommend this place to anyone visiting Boston!

Wow. Had some time. This was quick. We got meter parking directly across the street.
Our kids enjoyed the display and the weird acoustics. I found a storyboard and contributed one.

name: Boston Public Market
reviews: Tried the smoked salmon on a bagel and it was absolutely delicious! Must go to Red's Best and try their food! Me and my husband got: clam chowder, lobster bisque, salmon burger and oysters. The oysters are SO FRESH! Just squeeze a little bit lemon on it and that is all you need! Enjoy the true taste itself from those fresh oysters!

Love the Boston public market! There is a something for everyone here. You got seafood, meat, alcohol, coffee and a number of different food stands. Personally, loved the bagel spot (fresh bagels every morning) that can be served with butter or fancy it up into a full sandwich. If you are visiting Boston, consider checking this place out for a quick bite or even a souvenir to take home

The Market is awesome. It deserves 5 stars because it has a ton of variety and the people who work there are so friendly.

But, I couldn't give it 5 stars because of the guy who was loitering near the bathrooms. He appeared to have likely just shot up heroin and just lent a funky vibe to the place because he was sitting there rocking back and forth, talking to himself, and frequently scratching his hands and arms.

Aside from that, its a great place

Overly prices local goods (or locally made) you may consider treating yourself to once in a blue moon. 
Tasted some great chocolate, but at $10 a bar, could not do more than the tasting.
Large meet and fish stalls, wine and beer cellar, some non edible items as well as a fresh fruit and veggie stand. Selection of to go food and Dr pasta. 
Donuts, ice cream, macaroon, fudge and much more to please your sweet tooth.
Lots of local food shops inside. Or you can grab some groceries outside. I enjoyed the hot apple cider the past two trips here. Definitely will go back for more drinks and pastries.

name: Make Way for Ducklings
address: 4 Charles St S, Boston, MA 02116, USA
reviews: If this is a landmark that has generated your interest then you have been through the majestic and beyond amazing Boston Commons to find this creation. It’s Adored by kids and my friend had to wait to get her shots. It’s fun to try angles to get all the ducklings in a row. There are real ducks nearby in the pond as well. Beware the chipmunks, they had a grudge against my friend for some reason.

As you can see, our Frenchie, Kenny G had a fascination with the ducks when we use to live in Boston. During different seasons, holidays, and when the local sports teams were playing for a championship, someone use to dress the ducks up. Always great for a photo op.
Beloved sculpture from the book, "Make Way For Ducklings." I love that they ducks are seasonally dressed. Seek them out.
I love these ducklings. Such a joyful and fun and very-Boston statue.
I couldn't resist stopping by these adorable ducklings while on my Freedom Trail journey. You don't need to be a kid to enjoy the sheer workmanship put into each duckling and mom.

name: Bunker Hill
reviews: It's located in a gorgeous area in Boston. But a whole lot immediately around it as far as restaurants but the neighborhood is top notch. Great history there and a few stories around the area but would recommend buying a guidebook at one of the parks like Boston Common to get full details. Such a rich historical area is not to be missed.

It was a wonderful experience, i walked the entire freedom trail and it led me here at the end. It was nice after a long walk to relax on the lawn of bunker hill and just enjoy the nice cool air after a long walk through the city, and after you visit the monument you can cross the street to see the museum.
Nice relaxing place with grassy hills to take a nap after a good day's hike.

I enjoyed the 200+ steps to the top of the monument even though the view from the top was less than spectacular with the small windows and crowded room.  

For those of you not sure whether you are up for the climb, there is a railing but  the steps are fairly narrow, there is traffic coming both ways and there are no benches.

You need to get a time slotted ticket from the Bunker Hill Museum (43 Monument Sq) in order to be allowed to climb.
Fun to walk up to from the Charlestown landing

name: Hatch Memorial Shell
address: 47 David G Mugar Way, Boston, MA 02108, USA
reviews:
This was the first time we drove up to see the Fourth of July celebration and it  is worth the long drive.  The last time was Williams lady performance back in the 60s and last week was no exception.  Listening to the Boston Pops on a beautiful evening was enchanting.

The area  in front  of the amphitheater is a nice grassy area to spread out your blankets and enjoy the evening.  As you would assume the music was excellent and the opportunity to talk to people from all over is a plus.  I met a couple from England who wanted to experience a traditional  fourth and they were so very pleased. Where we say we also could see the fireworks which were fun to watch.  When the canon went off it was LOUD and so many people jumped.  I think we forget how noisy those are.
 I must admit the audience and the people of Boston were especially kind.  My husband  is in a wheelchair and the people couldn't have been nicer and thoughtful.  So many people have support and assistance when needed.  They asked first to make sure to respect him.  Thank you Boston

I've been to a few events at the Hatch Memorial Shell.

Going on July 3rd to see the Pops dress rehearsal here is one of my favorite Boston traditions. 

Going to the Water Lantern Festival hosted here was cool - but not as streamlined as the more established events (like the Pops concert).

There are also cool statues and great views of the city - Boston and Cambridge - making it a nice stopping point any time.

It's in a lovely location along the river. By bike or foot it is easy to access - there are foot bridges across Storrow Drive making it safe to access. There is not a train stop super close though so plan ahead for that!

I was expecting it to be a lot larger than it turned out to be. Didn’t go for anything in particular just saw it on the map and wanted to check it out in person. It is located by a really nice trail that goes around the water. Would recommend a 5 minute walk past.

An awesome place to watching a show. Many free or cheap events throughout the year including Movies,  and concerts. The biggest event being the Boston Pops fourth of July Spectacular. Overall its a great spot along the banks of the Charles River.
Beautiful place to chill. You can have fun picnic with your family when there is no ticketed event. Enjoy the Charles River on the edge. Have fun walking, jogging, or biking

name: The Institute of Contemporary Art
address: 25 Harbor Shore Dr, Boston, MA 02210, USA
reviews: I rode my bike there from my South End home and loved the exhibits. However, I'd have a very different opinion if I had planned this  with friends and had to pay for parking because there were only a few rooms with artwork open since the museum had closed off some important rooms while they installed new exhibits. Admission was free because of this but I would have been very disappointed if I wasn't a local. There's really nothing else in the area to see, unlike the Avenue of the Arts in the Fenway where you have many choices of museums within an easy walk of one another.  I must add that the view from the glassed-in deck is one of the best in town of the waterfront and harbor.

The ICA Boston is one of the most serene museum experiences that I’ve had. Located on the water there’s an incredible viewing deck that looks out onto the water on the fourth floor. The exhibitions are relevant and very contemporary, usually featuring a diverse roster of artists and themes.

Love it here, the artists that they procure are amazing. They are always finding someone who designs and creates that makes one think and reflect not only about themselves but what is going on in the world. I go almost monthly because the vibe there is thrilling.

My wife an I went to the love is calling exhibit. It was cool, but only got to spend 2 minutes in there which was not enough time at all to take in everything and take pictures. There also isn't much to see in the gallery.

Nice museum, I always come here on the free Thursday evenings. Decent size, you don’t get tired walking around since only a few floors have exhibits. Have some interesting exhibits. Parking seems a little expense in the lot right outside the museum. Love the gift shop, haha.

name: Boston Light
address: Little Brewster Island, Boston, MA, USA
reviews: To clear up some history: the current lighthouse at Boston Light is NOT America's first lighthouse, it is America's second lighthouse. The original Boston light, which was the first in the country, was torched by those pesky redcoats during the American Revolution. Then New Jersey pulled up and built a lighthouse before Boston Light could be rebuilt. TLDR, the current Boston Light is the second-oldest. Still dope tho.
Boston light is America's first LIGHTHOUSE
I do Boston harbor tours and we always include Boston light.

name: The Lawn On D
reviews: Wonderful place to hang out and bring friends and family. Swings are SUPER FUN, they have lots of games and even music sometimes, but also drinks and snacks. It is even romantic enough for a fun date location after dark. Sometimes there are freebies given out for partnered events with other companies. They do close for the winter tho because nobody wants to be outside in freezing Boston temperatures. I do recommend everyone visit here to see how fun it can be!
Sterile space with fake grass made for compulsory corporate-sponsored fun. No charm. Gentrification has sucked the air out of the whole vicinity.
It seems like a lot of fun and different; place is closed for the season (website didn't inform about this).
Great place to spend an afternoon in sunshine. Swing on the swings. Enjoy live entertainment in the tent or enjoy a rousing game of cornhole.

Nice place,clean,few games around to play ,security is around. People do hog the swings though which is not good since its the main attraction going there and everyone is hoping to get a turn. I Think having a timer on them would be a good idea,just a thought

name: Christopher Columbus Waterfront Park
reviews: This is a popular place for picnics, wedding pics and just hanging around. Plenty of greenspace facing Boston Harbor for everyone. The space is very clean and well maintained. The arch way is always decorated during the Holidays adding a festive glow.
Took pictures of my friend here for her announcement of which dental school she was going to. Great park to view the water, the city, and just enjoy time outside at! Would reccomend!

Gorgeous little park! You have the water a glance away, the Rose Kennedy Greenway across the street, and plenty of daytime events in the warmer months. In the colder months, closer to the holidays, they light up the archway and it's just an amazing spot for a walk after dark.

It’s so beautiful! Amazing! Serene and calm and just beautiful. So many people are just chilling and relaxing. It’s a family hangout and a couple hangout. You can easily just sit and spend time here letting time fly. Completely recommend visiting this place.
Took this shot on Christmas night! My favorite time to go to Boston its literally like a ghost town! Enjoy🎅❤💚

name: MIT Museum
address: 265 Massachusetts Ave Building N51, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA
reviews: Wow! Very cool museum. My two boys 12 and 8 absolutely loved it. It’s relatively small so I would plan about 2 hours to see everything. My kids loved  all the robots and technology. The presentation on the slide ruler was fascinating. It’s a great place to take the family.

If you love science, particularly physics, you will enjoy this museum. I found it kind of interesting. Most of it was dedicated to the science of movement and part of it to image and video. It is actually pretty small, and you can easily get through it in about an hour. There is an extensive part of the museum that feature boat construction. I expected something totally different going there (like cutting edge tech, robotics etc.), but I still enjoyed it.

My family had a fantastic visit today at the museum. From the minute we walked in Beth greeted us and was the best ambassador!  Lots of cool exhibits from robotics to the Polaroid experience and nautical science made this a great place to visit at MIT!!

From the great conceptual motorized sculptures to current innovations to the history of technology... And even art... This is a fun and stimulating small museum, a short walk from the MIT main campus, and a little further from Harvard.

This museum is a great place for kids and adults. It is a fascinating blend of a science museum and an art museum. 

The kinetic sculpture exhibit is incredible. Other major exhibits cover ship building and the history of Polaroid camera.

Parking is not provided, so you'll need to use a nearby garage or the street meters.

name: Old State House
reviews: Our docent was pretty incredible and made for a high quality experience. She did a great job explaining the history of the location, and connecting it with current events. She even tactfully managed some of the more "uninformed" adults in our group very well. It was a shorter tour than most, but very engaging. I would recommend visiting.

The building was built in 1798 and was designed by the famous eighteenth-century architect Charles Bullfinch. In addition, he designed the United States Capitol in Washington, DC. The interior of the building is magnificent, and the flag hall is located under the dome to collect the flags of the civil war period. Frescoes about Revere's Flying Riding News and the "Boston Tea Party Case" decorate the Senate staircase. A famous wooden fish, Massachusetts' "sacred cod", hangs in the lobby of the House, demonstrating the importance of fishing here since 1784. Underground archives and museums contain precious historical documents such as the Mayflower Peace Treaty.

I wasn’t able to go inside as I had a stroller and two kids and it’s not wheelchair accessible but this is definitely a place to see if you have the chance. The massacre site is just behind it and we saw that. It helps to know the history of what actually happened. When you know what happened you can picture what those involved saw at the time and how their surroundings might have affected the outcome of the massacre.

This historic building has been dwarfed by skyscrapers, so you come upon it almost as a surprise. It's on a little triangle between busy thoroughfares. Yet, it retains its 18th century elegance and sense of history. This is where the Boston Massacre happened - the guides will tell you. Here's to the guides - They do a fantastic job. I've taken two separate tours with two separate guides. They're all fantastic!

It small and fun to explore, but maybe not worth the cost of admission. It's quite cramped since you have to fight with an ocean of tourists to move around in tiny hallways and rooms, but everything is beautifully preserved. Maybe try to go here at an off time, as peak hours are going to be a little miserable.

name: Harvard Square
address: 18 Brattle St Suite 352, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA
reviews: Harvard Square is awesome. There are lots to do especially in the summer you will hear musicians outside. There is a man in front of the main train station that paints & sells his art. Lots of shops & a variety of restaurants here. Also, on 42 Brattle St. there is the Cambridge Center for Adult Education, which has a variety of classes including cooking, dance, music, business etc. Also, Central Square & Porter Square are within walking distance with tons of eateries. Harvard Square also has access to trains & buses to get you where you need to go! Must visit!

Nice area to walk around without loads of crowds. The campus and buildings are beautiful. Very safe area at night! 
Lots of great restaurants and things to do in walking distance. 
If you are looking for shopping there aren’t as many options as there used to be. The shops that are here are great though! I wish there were more boutiques but otherwise I enjoy the area!

Harvard University is definitely worth your time. If you get to it, begin your Harvard tour here. Firstly, it's a main thoroughfare with great historical buildings nearby. Next, many stores, gift shops, a bike stand (recommended) and a bus stop are on here. Finally, it provides access to the main Harvard square where most of the historic buildings are clustered. Tour guides available.

There's nothing extraordinary about this Square, but it's the heartbeat of the university and it feels cool to be standing there at this world famous university. 

The main attraction here is the statue of  John Harvard, the man who founded the university. It's also known as the "statue of three lies". I'll leave that for you to find out why.

If you intend to visit Harvard, you cannot miss this. It's a must-visit. At the very least, you can admire the architecture of the buildings around you.
Food for every palate. Fun shops. Harvard Bookstore is right across the street from the Red Line T station. Definitely check out Otto's Pizza. Better to visit during warm weather months.

name: Harvard Yard
reviews:
Good look at history. It's kind of amazing to imagine how for almost 300 hundred years scholars have been walking the same paths as you if you were to visit the yard. Some go the buildings here are 250-300 yrs old. And the guided tour (which is free and can be found near the Harvard sq. T station) is full of quirky history. Don't forget to rub fake John Harvard's shoes if you want to get into Harvard. 

Note to the Traveller: the Harvard campus is way bigger and than the yard and the art museum and museum of natural history are wonderful places to visit. You might also consider buying cheaper H paraphernalia at shops around the yard instead of at the Co-op store.

It's Harvard, an iconic American Ivy league university. Honestly, I had no desire to visit but my wife, being from another country, had the curiosity and the last say. What can I say, it's a pretty campus with a rich history. If you really would like inside information o would advise one of the many free walking tours. Honestly, besides the history and it's stature, it's just a college campus. However, if you have a thing for campuses and or Harvard, by all means enjoy...

Did not expect it to be that cold, this late in March. But freezing nose and fingers aside, we were quite happy with our guide on the prospective students tour. Quite knowledgeable about the campus geography and history (This is Harvard so that's quite a lot of history) and done on time too Did not expect it to be that cold, this late in March. But freezing nose and fingers aside, we were quite happy with our guide on the prospective students tour. Quite knowledgeable about the campus geography and history (This is Harvard so that's quite a lot of history) and done on time too
Worth seeing if you are visiting Boston. Their guided tours are free, but fill up very fast.  Make sure you call early and sign up.

The park isn’t really that interesting other than being near Harvard. It gets incredibly crowded during the summers with tourists from all around. This park should not be your “go-to” if you are traveling to Boston. Boston Common is much prettier and well maintenance than Harvard Yard.

name: Boston Harbor Cruises
reviews: Great fun !! Cruise experience was really good. Superb Boston downtown and Boston skyline views. Loved to take many photos and videos of the cruise. The harbor ride was exciting and the boat was really cool. The guides were giving all the information. The cruise went really well. Highly recommended.
Had so much fun! Definitely a relaxing way to see all of Boston harbor and we learned some interesting historical facts to go along with the view. Highly recommend!
Great way to see the city. They will give you the history of a lot of what you are looking at. Top decks on starboard side is where you will get the best views. Very enjoyable experience.
Very informative and friendly staff.  Reasonable prices.  Easy way to go to Salem.  If the weather is great, get out of Boston for a bit.  See history in Salem!

Port cities grow up around their harbors, so getting out on the water is the best way to get a feel for them.  The harbor tour didn't disappoint.  Very good guide, talked enough (boat was big enough to get away from her completely it you wanted though - smart), but not continuously and was great about answering questions in person when she wasn't talking.

name: Haymarket
reviews:
Great place to get your produce cheap for the week. Lots of options for great prices, I go every weekend and get a week's worth of veggies and fish. Last week I was able to get 2 pounds of fresh haddock, two things of raspberries, blackberries, a pound of potato's, broccoli and some really good cheeses for all under $20. Such a great way to start the week. The market happens every Friday and Saturday from around noon to four I believe. I'd recommend you to bring bags unless they will be giving you plastic bags which you may want to avoid.

My diets protein is based off fish so I love the money I save here. I've gotten fresh salmon for as low as $4 a lb, if you get a few lbs you can haggle down your price. Best is the fresh tuna stakes you can get for around $3 a pound! And swordfish for the same! Such variety in the food I can afford now. When I go to the grocery store I just end up buying bags of frozen fish that cost much more then the fresh fish I'm getting here. I will tend to buy it then freeze it into portions for the week or for a few weeks. Saves me a lot sense the more you get the cheaper you can get it for.

The best place to get fresh produce. Fridays and Saturday morning are the best times to go. After that you are probably going to have to search for the good stuff but it's not impossible. They have everything from fresh herbs to several types of fish, oysters and clams. You will save half your money going here compared to the supermarket. Shop here you won't be sorry at all

The vendors are rude. But there are a few vendors I go back to because they're more personable. The produce is cheap and you do in most occasions get what you pay for.  But every now and then, it's a good deal.
Shop it and get great, to good, to OK produce all at very good prices. Wonderful admixture of ethnicities and people both buying and selling. I really dig my jaunts here.
Would give 10 stars if possible. So fun. So cheap. So good. So green. What's not to love? Bring your own bag for extra credit.

name: Commonwealth Avenue Mall
reviews: Beautiful stretch of Comm Ave. Houses reminded me of Paris.
Master architecture, greenways and happy dogs make for a great stroll.
This is a very beautiful area! I love the buildings and the way this area was built. There's tons of unique restaurants and shops around to see also.

Commonwealth Avenue Mall is a lovely place to sit under the canopy of the trees, relax and enjoy nature, to observe people stroll along the mall, children running around and playing, and to see all manner of activity along Commonwealth Avenue.
Love this park. It's one of my favorite spots in Boston, and I've visited this park on most of my trips to the city in the last few years. I'm sure I'll be back on any future trips to Boston.

name: Cocktails & Cannoli
reviews: Wow! This walking tour was amazing. A bit of history, lots of recommendations. The treats and cocktails were great. Elisabeth was super personable and a great guide. Would recommend for anyone coming to Boston.

Pat was the best host you can imagine for a walking tour. The dessert / drink stops were spaced well and had the perfect combinations! You get to see landmarks like Old North Church, and also learn about the history of the area in a way that leaves you feeling like a local. There were tons of interesting fun facts as well as water and great food and drinks (it was such a bonus to skip the lines for everything!) It was also great that all the shop owners were super friendly with our guide and quick to serve us.

The best part of the tour was that you get to try one cannoli of each of the two best shops in the North End. Instead of waiting for 30 minutes at one of the two, you get to do a blind test to compare and see the different styles that each shop has. Choose your favorite. It was an amazing way to spend the afternoon and super fun! Highly recommend!

My boyfriend and I had a fabulous time on this unique tour. It was incredibly well organized - whenever we showed up to a place, the cocktail or dessert sample was already ready to go. Everything was delicious! Pat, the owner and primary guide, is a resident of the North End so our walking tour was peppered with historical facts and sites as well as a local's perspective. He was very personable and engaging. I highly recommend this tour and will happily return in the future!

GREAT EXPERIENCE! Pat (our tour guide) was so accommodating with everything from booking the tour, communicating throughout the process, and overall making the tour such an amazing part of our Boston trip. We went as a group of 12 girls and hands down this was one of our favorite parts! Not only did we get to eat and drink our way through Boston, we also learned a lot of fun facts and history. I would without a doubt highly recommend this tour!!!

Great tour! very well organized, lots of information (Pat is very knowledgeable) and very good cocktails and desserts. I particularly loved the visit to the chocolate place and the Old North church, which had its own guide explanation.

name: Old Town Trolley Tours of Boston
reviews: Tours are very informative and entertaining. You're able to hop on and off at 15 stops around the city. When it's cold the windows do limit the ability to take photos but over all a definite recommendation for anyone visiting

The key ingredient to all of these tours is the tour guide. Some are too much, some are not enough. Some too many personal notes, and some too many dry facts.  But... they get you around to all the key spots on your own schedule because they are hop on, hop off. I love them!
Excellent way to tour Boston.  The tour guides are very knowledgeable and buses every 30 minutes st each stop was very convenient.

We found a trolley stop  but no prices were listed. We went to ask a driver about how it worked and he said just hop on and we'll take care of you at another stop. We were surprised about an hour & many stops later to find out it was $46 a person. We thought that seemed a little bit expensive. He dropped us off at the end to pay. At that point we were given an out-of-date map. I mean the stops were the same but it said the deals that you would have got in 2018. It mentioned that we should have gotten about $50 worth of coupons so that we could have gotten off at stops and gone to museums at a discount or for free. We did not get any coupon books and we did not find out that it was an option until we already finished the day and paid and left and were looking at the map. I would do this again but I would strongly recommend starting at a stop where you can pay and getting all of the information up front. If you got on in the morning and got off at each stop and visited things you could spend an entire day doing this! It is a great deal of fun but a little more communication up front would have been helpful and actually getting what we were supposed to would have been terrific too.
Great drivers, great time.  Love being able to get off and on....if you really want to use this trolley as a way to easily see a lot of Boston, buy the 2 day pass...1 day was not long enough !

name: Chinatown Gate
address: John F Fitzgerald Surface Rd, Boston, MA 02111, USA
reviews: People take pictures here but nothing special. Lots of elderly hang out there. You will find some people playing Chinese chess

Beautiful place and definitely worth visiting. It will probably be a little crowded, and maybe a little dirty too. But, it's a nice place and I like how it looks a lot more than Chinatown in New York City. Go, enjoy it, and take beautiful pictures!

Chinatown is a great place and has a few blocks in Boston of what feels somewhat like the American understanding of China.

One of few places in the city where you can find shops, stores and restaurants open on Christmas.
